items.title: I can classify fibres as natural, synthetic, or semi-synthetic based on their source
items.what: Fibres are grouped by origin: natural fibres come from plants or animals, synthetic fibres are made entirely from petroleum chemicals in factories, and semi-synthetic fibres start with natural materials (usually wood pulp) but undergo chemical processing.
items.why: This classification helps you understand where materials come from and their likely environmental impacts, from renewable animal and plant sources to petroleum-based manufacturing.
items.example: Wool (from sheep) and cotton (from plants) are natural fibres. Polyester and nylon are synthetic fibres made from petroleum. Rayon/viscose and lyocell are semi-synthetic because they start as wood pulp but are chemically processed into fibres.

subtopic.name: Fibre Classification and Properties
subtopic.what: This subtopic covers how textile fibres are classified into natural, synthetic, and semi-synthetic categories based on their source. You will learn the difference between staple and filament fibres, and understand the key properties that determine how fibres are used.
subtopic.why: Understanding fibre classification helps you identify what your clothes are made from and predict how they will perform. Knowing fibre properties is essential for choosing appropriate materials for different purposes, from activewear to formal clothing.

items.title: I can distinguish between staple fibres and filament fibres
items.what: Staple fibres are short lengths (a few centimetres to about 50cm) that must be twisted together to create yarn. Filament fibres are very long continuous strands that can be used directly or cut into shorter lengths.
items.why: This distinction affects how fibres are processed into yarn and the characteristics of the final fabric, including texture, strength, and appearance.
items.example: Cotton, wool, and linen are staple fibres that need spinning. Silk is the only natural filament fibre, with a single cocoon producing 600-900 metres of continuous thread. All synthetic fibres (polyester, nylon) are produced as filaments through spinnerets.

items.title: I can identify examples of animal fibres and their sources
items.what: Animal fibres are natural fibres obtained from animals. The main animal fibres are wool from sheep, silk from silkworm cocoons, and specialty fibres from goats, alpacas, and rabbits.
items.why: Animal fibres have unique properties like natural warmth, moisture management, and biodegradability that make them valuable for specific textile applications.
items.example: Wool comes from sheep (especially Merino). Silk comes from silkworm cocoons. Cashmere comes from cashmere goats, mohair from Angora goats, alpaca fibre from alpacas, and angora from Angora rabbits.

items.title: I can identify examples of plant fibres and their sources
items.what: Plant fibres are natural fibres obtained from various parts of plants, including seed pods, stems, and leaves. The most common plant fibres are cotton, linen, and hemp.
items.why: Plant fibres are renewable resources that have been used for thousands of years and remain important for everyday textiles due to their comfort, breathability, and biodegradability.
items.example: Cotton fibre surrounds seeds inside the cotton boll. Linen comes from the stem of the flax plant. Hemp comes from the stem of the hemp plant. Jute and sisal are other plant fibres used for ropes and sacking.

items.title: I can explain key fibre properties and their importance for textile selection
items.what: Key fibre properties include absorbency (moisture uptake), strength, elasticity (stretch and recovery), thermal properties (warmth/coolness), flammability (fire resistance), and biodegradability (how quickly it breaks down).
items.why: Understanding properties helps designers choose the right fibre for each purpose—a sportswear designer needs different properties than someone making children's sleepwear or winter coats.
items.example: For summer sportswear, you might choose cotton (high absorbency, breathable) or polyester (quick-drying, lightweight). For children's sleepwear, wool is preferred because it has high fire resistance and won't ignite until 570-600°C, compared to cotton at 255°C.

items.title: I can describe Australia's significance in global wool production
items.what: Australia is the world's largest producer of apparel wool, producing about 25% of global supply. The industry involves approximately 68.5 million sheep producing 280 million kg of greasy wool annually, with 82-86% exported to China.
items.why: Understanding Australia's role in wool production connects local agriculture to global textile supply chains and demonstrates the economic importance of fibre production.
items.example: Australia has been the world's largest wool producer since 1870. The first Merino sheep arrived in 1797. Today, the major wool-producing states are New South Wales, Victoria, Western Australia, and South Australia.

subtopic.name: Wool Production in Australia
subtopic.what: This subtopic covers Australia's wool industry, including the importance of Merino sheep, the stages of wool processing from shearing to fabric, and the unique properties that make wool valuable. You will also learn about wool grading and the Woolmark certification system.
subtopic.why: Australia produces about 25% of the world's apparel wool, making it a globally significant industry. Understanding wool production demonstrates how managed agricultural environments work and why wool remains valuable despite synthetic alternatives.

items.title: I can explain why Merino sheep are important for fine wool production
items.what: Merino sheep produce the finest wool fibres, measuring as thin as 12-20 microns (a micron is one-millionth of a metre). Different Merino strains are suited to different Australian environments based on their fibre fineness.
items.why: Finer wool fibres feel softer against the skin, drape better, and can be woven into lighter, more luxurious fabrics, commanding higher prices in the market.
items.example: Saxon Merinos produce very fine wool (≤20 microns) suited to high-rainfall areas. Peppin Merinos produce 21-22 micron wool for wheat-sheep zones. South Australian Strongwool Merinos produce 23-26 micron wool for dry pastoral areas. Human hair is about 70 microns thick for comparison.

items.title: I can describe the eight stages of wool processing from sheep to fabric
items.what: Wool processing involves: 1) Shearing (removing fleece), 2) Skirting and classing (sorting quality), 3) Wool auction, 4) Scouring (washing), 5) Carding (aligning fibres), 6) Combing (for worsted wool), 7) Spinning (creating yarn), 8) Weaving or knitting (fabric construction).
items.why: Understanding the complete production chain shows how raw agricultural products are transformed into finished textiles through multiple managed processes.
items.example: A skilled shearer removes a 4-5 kg fleece in 2-3 minutes. Scouring removes lanolin, suint, and dirt at 60-65°C, reducing weight by about 30%. Spinning twists fibres together—more twist creates stronger, thinner yarn for weaving; less twist creates softer yarn for knitwear.

items.title: I can explain wool's moisture management and temperature regulation properties
items.what: Wool can absorb 30-35% of its own weight in moisture without feeling wet because it has a water-resistant outer layer and absorbent inner core. The natural crimp in wool fibres creates air pockets that trap warmth while also allowing cooling through moisture evaporation.
items.why: These properties explain why wool is popular for activewear and outdoor clothing—it keeps wearers comfortable in both hot and cold conditions.
items.example: Merino wool base layers are popular with hikers because the wool absorbs sweat from skin and releases it slowly into the air, preventing that clammy feeling. The same garment provides warmth in cold weather through trapped air in the crimped fibres.

items.title: I can explain why wool is naturally fire-resistant
items.what: Wool will not ignite until it reaches 570-600°C (cotton ignites at just 255°C). Wool also requires 25.2% oxygen to burn, but our atmosphere only contains 21% oxygen, so wool struggles to sustain a flame and tends to smoulder and self-extinguish.
items.why: Fire resistance is a critical safety property, making wool suitable for applications where fire safety is important, such as aircraft interiors and children's sleepwear.
items.example: Aircraft seat covers are often made from wool because of its fire-resistant properties. If wool does catch fire, it smoulders rather than producing flames and doesn't melt or drip like synthetic fibres, reducing burn injuries.

items.title: I can interpret wool quality grades based on micron count
items.what: Wool quality is primarily determined by fibre diameter measured in microns. Grades range from ultrafine (<15.5 microns) used for luxury fashion, through fine (18.6-20.5 microns) for quality suiting, to strong/broad (>23.5 microns) used for carpets.
items.why: Understanding grading helps you interpret wool product quality and price differences, and explains why some wool products cost significantly more than others.
items.example: Ultrafine wool under 15.5 microns commands the highest prices and is used for luxury next-to-skin garments. Medium wool (20.6-23.5 microns) is used for outerwear and blankets. Strong wool over 23.5 microns goes into carpets and industrial applications.

subtopic.why: Australia produces about 25% of the world's apparel wool, making it a globally significant industry. Understanding wool production demonstrates how managed agricultural environments work and why wool remains valuable despite synthetic alternatives.

items.title: I can explain what the Woolmark certification guarantees about a product
items.what: The Woolmark logo, created in 1964, certifies wool content: Woolmark means 100% pure new wool, Woolmark Blend means 50-99.9% new wool, and Wool Blend means 30-49.9% new wool. Products must pass testing for fibre content, colourfastness, strength, and wash performance.
items.why: Certification systems help consumers make informed purchases and ensure quality standards are maintained in the wool industry.
items.example: A jumper with the Woolmark logo is guaranteed to contain 100% pure new wool and has been tested for colour that won't fade, physical strength, and ability to withstand washing according to care instructions.

items.title: I can describe the silk production process (sericulture)
items.what: Sericulture involves raising silkworms (Bombyx mori) through their lifecycle: eggs hatch into larvae that eat mulberry leaves for 23-28 days, then spin cocoons producing 600-900 metres of continuous silk filament over 2-3 days. Cocoons are harvested before moths emerge to preserve the continuous filament.
items.why: Silk is the only natural filament fibre and understanding its unique production explains both its luxury status and the ethical concerns some people have about traditional silk production.
items.example: It takes approximately 3,000 cocoons to produce 1 kg of silk, and 104 kg of mulberry leaves to feed those silkworms. The silkworm grows to 10,000 times its original size during the larva stage. Peace silk allows moths to emerge naturally but produces shorter fibres.

subtopic.name: Natural Fibres: Animal and Plant
subtopic.what: This subtopic covers silk production and luxury animal fibres (cashmere, mohair, alpaca, angora), as well as plant fibres including cotton, linen, and hemp. You will learn about production processes, unique properties, and common misconceptions about bamboo fabric.
subtopic.why: Natural fibres each have distinct properties that make them suitable for different applications. Understanding their production and characteristics helps you evaluate textile claims and make informed choices about fabric selection.

items.title: I can distinguish between cashmere, mohair, alpaca, and angora fibres
items.what: These luxury animal fibres come from different animals: cashmere from cashmere goat undercoat (must be <19 microns), mohair from Angora goats, alpaca from alpacas, and angora from Angora rabbits. Each has unique properties and production volumes.
items.why: Students commonly confuse these fibres, especially angora (from rabbits) and mohair (from Angora goats). Knowing the differences helps identify quality and authenticity.
items.example: Cashmere goats produce only 150-200 grams per year, making cashmere expensive. Alpaca fibre is 3-7 times warmer than wool due to hollow fibres. Angora from rabbits is 6 times warmer than wool. Mohair from Angora goats has exceptional lustre and durability.

items.title: I can describe the cotton growing cycle and ginning process
items.what: Cotton grows over 150-180 days from planting through flowering to boll opening. The cotton fibre surrounds seeds inside the boll. Ginning separates fibres from seeds, with 35-42% becoming usable lint, 48-55% cottonseed, and 3-10% waste.
items.why: Cotton is the world's most popular natural fibre, and understanding its production explains Australia's significant cotton industry and the water management challenges involved.
items.example: Australian cotton is grown mainly in the Murray-Darling Basin (91% of production). A healthy cotton plant produces 100-120 bolls, each containing about 500,000 individual fibres. Australia's yields are approximately 3 times the world average due to advanced farming practices.

items.title: I can explain why cotton gets stronger when wet
items.what: Unlike most fibres which weaken when wet, cotton increases in strength by 20-25% when wet. This occurs because water molecules form hydrogen bonds with the cellulose in cotton fibres, helping hold them together more tightly.
items.why: This unusual property explains why cotton can withstand repeated washing without falling apart, making it practical for everyday clothing and household textiles.
items.example: Cotton is approximately 90% cellulose. When you wash cotton clothing, the hydrogen bonds between water and cellulose actually strengthen the fabric. This is why cotton t-shirts and jeans can be machine washed hundreds of times.

items.title: I can describe the linen retting process and explain why it is necessary
items.what: Retting is controlled bacterial decomposition used to break down the pectin (plant glue) binding linen fibres to the flax stem. Dew retting spreads stalks in fields for about 3 weeks; water retting submerges them for 10-30 days. Over-retting damages fibres; under-retting makes separation impossible.
items.why: Retting is the critical step that determines linen quality. Understanding this process shows why linen production is labour-intensive and explains linen's higher cost compared to cotton.
items.example: After retting, scutching beats the stalks to remove woody pieces, then hackling combs out fibres. Linen is 2-3 times stronger than cotton and can last up to 30 years. Australia has no significant linen production because flax needs cool, moist climates.

items.title: I can explain why hemp is considered an environmentally sustainable fibre
items.what: Hemp reaches maturity in just 90-120 days (versus cotton's 150-180), requires about 50% less water than cotton, needs no pesticides due to natural pest resistance, and produces 2 times more fibre per hectare than cotton.
items.why: As sustainability becomes more important in textiles, understanding hemp's environmental advantages helps evaluate claims about eco-friendly fabrics.
items.example: Hemp was legalised for food in Australia in November 2017, with about 9,000 hectares cultivated in 2019-2020. Hemp fibre is 3-4 times stronger than cotton. The deep roots prevent erosion and can remove toxins from soil (phytoremediation).

items.title: I can evaluate claims about bamboo fabric and explain why most bamboo clothing is misleading
items.what: Most bamboo fabric is actually rayon/viscose made from bamboo, not true bamboo fibre. The bamboo is dissolved in harsh chemicals (sodium hydroxide, carbon disulfide) and extruded through spinnerets. After this chemical processing, no trace of original bamboo properties remains.
items.why: Understanding this misconception helps you critically evaluate marketing claims about eco-friendly textiles and recognise greenwashing.
items.example: The US Federal Trade Commission requires such products to be labelled as rayon made from bamboo rather than simply bamboo. True mechanically-processed bamboo linen exists but is rare, rough-textured, and expensive. The soft bamboo clothing commonly sold is chemically identical to rayon from any plant source.

items.title: I can explain how synthetic fibres are manufactured using spinnerets
items.what: Synthetic fibre production involves polymerisation (creating long-chain molecules from petroleum chemicals), melting or dissolving the polymer, extruding through a spinneret (metal plate with tiny 0.05-0.1mm holes), solidification, and drawing (stretching to align molecules).
items.why: Understanding the manufacturing process explains why synthetic fibres have consistent properties, why they are derived from non-renewable petroleum, and how their properties can be precisely controlled.
items.example: The spinneret works like a showerhead with microscopic holes. Round holes create standard fibres, triangular holes create fibres with enhanced lustre, and hollow centres create fibres with better insulation. Polyester fibres are stretched up to 5 times their original length during drawing.

subtopic.name: Synthetic and Semi-Synthetic Fibres
subtopic.what: This subtopic covers how synthetic fibres are manufactured from petroleum, including polyester, nylon, and acrylic. You will also learn about semi-synthetic fibres like rayon and lyocell, which start from natural materials but undergo chemical processing.
subtopic.why: Synthetic fibres now dominate global textile production, with polyester alone accounting for 57% of all fibres. Understanding their manufacture, properties, and environmental impacts is essential for informed textile choices.

items.title: I can describe polyester's properties, advantages, and environmental concerns
items.what: Polyester (PET) is the world's most used fibre at 57% of global production. It has very low moisture absorption (0.4-1%), is wrinkle-resistant, strong, and quick-drying. However, it is made from petroleum, takes 20-200 years to decompose, and releases microplastic fibres when washed.
items.why: Understanding polyester's dominance and trade-offs helps evaluate textile choices between performance benefits and environmental costs.
items.example: Polyester is produced using melt spinning at 260-270°C. Recycled polyester (rPET) from plastic bottles uses 59-79% less energy than virgin polyester. However, recycled polyester may release more microplastic fibres during washing than virgin polyester because the recycled fibres are often shorter and weaker.

subtopic.name: Synthetic and Semi-Synthetic Fibres

subtopic.why: Synthetic fibres now dominate global textile production, with polyester alone accounting for 57% of all fibres. Understanding their manufacture, properties, and environmental impacts is essential for informed textile choices.

items.title: I can explain nylon's historical significance and key properties
items.what: Nylon was the first fully synthetic fibre, invented on February 28, 1935. It is extremely strong (stronger than steel of the same diameter), has excellent elasticity and abrasion resistance, is lightweight and quick-drying, but takes 30-40 years to decompose.
items.why: Nylon's invention revolutionised textiles and demonstrates how synthetic fibres can provide properties impossible in natural materials.
items.example: When nylon stockings went on sale in 1940, stores sold out within hours and nylon riots occurred. Nylon's strength and elasticity make it ideal for hosiery, activewear, swimwear, parachutes, ropes, fishing nets, and carpet fibres.

subtopic.why: Synthetic fibres now dominate global textile production, with polyester alone accounting for 57% of all fibres. Understanding their manufacture, properties, and environmental impacts is essential for informed textile choices.

items.title: I can identify why acrylic is particularly problematic for microplastic pollution
items.what: Acrylic (containing at least 85% acrylonitrile) releases approximately 730,000 microplastic fibres per wash—about 5 times more than polyester-cotton blends. These tiny particles pass through washing machine filters and water treatment plants into waterways and oceans.
items.why: Understanding acrylic's microplastic contribution highlights how different synthetic fibres have different environmental impacts, informing purchasing and care decisions.
items.example: Synthetic textiles contribute 35% of ocean microplastics. A single wash can release 640,000-1,500,000 microfibres. Microplastics have been found in marine life, drinking water, food, and human blood. Acrylic takes approximately 200 years to decompose.

subtopic.why: Synthetic fibres now dominate global textile production, with polyester alone accounting for 57% of all fibres. Understanding their manufacture, properties, and environmental impacts is essential for informed textile choices.

items.title: I can distinguish between traditional viscose/rayon and lyocell production methods
items.what: Traditional viscose treats wood pulp with toxic chemicals including 17.5% sodium hydroxide and carbon disulfide, creating pollution. Lyocell (TENCEL) uses a closed-loop process with non-toxic NMMO solvent, recovering 99.8% for reuse with much less water and energy.
items.why: Semi-synthetic fibres show that natural source materials do not automatically mean sustainable production. Understanding the difference helps evaluate environmental claims.
items.example: Viscose was developed in the late 1800s as a cheaper silk alternative. Carbon disulfide is hazardous to workers and the environment. Lyocell biodegrades in approximately 55 days and is stronger than cotton when wet. Both start from wood pulp but have very different environmental impacts.

subtopic.name: Synthetic and Semi-Synthetic Fibres
subtopic.what: This subtopic covers how synthetic fibres are manufactured from petroleum, including polyester, nylon, and acrylic. You will also learn about semi-synthetic fibres like rayon and lyocell, which start from natural materials but undergo chemical processing.
subtopic.why: Synthetic fibres now dominate global textile production, with polyester alone accounting for 57% of all fibres. Understanding their manufacture, properties, and environmental impacts is essential for informed textile choices.

items.title: I can compare decomposition times of different synthetic and semi-synthetic fibres
items.what: Decomposition times vary significantly: lyocell takes about 55 days, nylon 30-40 years, polyester 20-200 years, and acrylic approximately 200 years. These times mean synthetic textiles can persist in landfill for generations.
items.why: Understanding end-of-life impacts is crucial for evaluating the full environmental footprint of textile choices.
items.example: The fashion industry produces about 92 million tonnes of textile waste globally each year. Compare these to natural fibres: linen decomposes in 2 weeks to a few months, cotton in 1 week to 5 months, and wool in 1-5 years depending on conditions.

items.title: I can define what makes an environment managed in fibre production
items.what: A managed environment is a production system where humans control key factors to optimise outcomes. This includes selecting breeds/varieties, controlling inputs (water, nutrients, pest management), managing timing (planting, harvesting), using technology for monitoring, and applying quality standards.
items.why: Understanding what management means helps you analyse how different fibre production systems operate along a spectrum from extensive to intensive control.
items.example: A sheep station manages breed selection, pasture rotation, and stocking rates. A cotton farm intensively manages irrigation, pest control, and harvest timing. A synthetic fibre factory precisely controls temperature, chemical concentrations, and humidity.

subtopic.name: Managed Environments
subtopic.what: This subtopic explains what makes an environment managed in fibre production, covering the spectrum from extensive sheep stations to intensive cotton farms to precisely controlled synthetic fibre factories. You will learn specific management practices for different fibre types.
subtopic.why: The Victorian Curriculum requires understanding how fibres are produced in managed environments. This knowledge demonstrates how human intervention optimises production outcomes across different agricultural and industrial settings.

items.title: I can describe management practices used in Australian wool production
items.what: Wool production management includes: breed selection suited to local conditions, rotational grazing and stocking rate adjustments, water management through bores and dams, health management (vaccination, parasite control, shearing timing), and technology like GPS tracking and drones.
items.why: Understanding wool management demonstrates how agricultural environments are manipulated to optimise both production quality and animal welfare.
items.example: Farmers choose fine-wool Merinos for higher-rainfall areas or stronger-wool breeds for harsh pastoral zones. Rotational grazing moves sheep between paddocks to allow pasture recovery. Supplementary feeding provides nutrition during drought. Digital platforms like WoolClip record fleece specifications.

subtopic.name: Managed Environments
subtopic.what: This subtopic explains what makes an environment managed in fibre production, covering the spectrum from extensive sheep stations to intensive cotton farms to precisely controlled synthetic fibre factories. You will learn specific management practices for different fibre types.
subtopic.why: The Victorian Curriculum requires understanding how fibres are produced in managed environments. This knowledge demonstrates how human intervention optimises production outcomes across different agricultural and industrial settings.

items.title: I can explain water and pest management in Australian cotton farming
items.what: Cotton requires intensive water management through furrow, centre-pivot, or drip irrigation, using 6-8 megalitres per hectare per season. Integrated Pest Management (IPM) combines monitoring, biological control, genetic resistance, and targeted spraying to minimise pesticide use.
items.why: Water is the critical limiting factor for Australian cotton, and understanding these management systems shows how technology and practices improve sustainability.
items.example: The cotton industry has improved water-use efficiency by about 40% since 1992. About 99% of Australian cotton is genetically modified for pest resistance. The myBMP (Best Management Practices) program requires farms to meet over 300 criteria across 10 operational areas.

subtopic.what: This subtopic explains what makes an environment managed in fibre production, covering the spectrum from extensive sheep stations to intensive cotton farms to precisely controlled synthetic fibre factories. You will learn specific management practices for different fibre types.
subtopic.why: The Victorian Curriculum requires understanding how fibres are produced in managed environments. This knowledge demonstrates how human intervention optimises production outcomes across different agricultural and industrial settings.

items.title: I can describe how harvest timing is managed in cotton production
items.what: Harvest timing is critical: too early means immature fibres and reduced quality; too late risks weather damage and increased trash. Defoliation using chemicals removes leaves 2-3 weeks before mechanical harvest to ease picking.
items.why: Timing management demonstrates how decisions throughout the growing season affect final fibre quality and yield.
items.example: Cotton bolls take 50-55 days from flowering to mature. A healthy plant may have 100-120 bolls, each containing about 500,000 individual fibres. Defoliation exposes the bolls and allows mechanical harvesters to collect cleaner cotton.

subtopic.name: Managed Environments
subtopic.what: This subtopic explains what makes an environment managed in fibre production, covering the spectrum from extensive sheep stations to intensive cotton farms to precisely controlled synthetic fibre factories. You will learn specific management practices for different fibre types.
subtopic.why: The Victorian Curriculum requires understanding how fibres are produced in managed environments. This knowledge demonstrates how human intervention optimises production outcomes across different agricultural and industrial settings.

items.title: I can compare management levels across wool, cotton, and synthetic fibre production
items.what: Management intensity varies: sheep stations use relatively light-touch management responding to environmental conditions; cotton farms have precise irrigation and pest control; synthetic fibre factories maintain exact temperature, chemical, and humidity control with continuous monitoring and automation.
items.why: Understanding this spectrum shows how different production systems require different management approaches to achieve consistent quality.
items.example: A wool grower adjusts stocking rates based on available feed. A cotton farmer programs precise irrigation schedules. A polyester factory maintains exact temperatures of 260-270°C during melt spinning and stretches fibres to exactly 5 times their original length.

items.title: I can compare the water footprints of different fibres
items.what: Water use varies dramatically: conventional cotton uses 8,000-20,000 litres per kg (one t-shirt requires approximately 2,700 litres), organic cotton uses 243-2,000 litres, hemp uses 2,000-3,400 litres, wool uses 500-800 litres, and polyester uses only 60-100 litres but requires petroleum.
items.why: Water footprint is a key sustainability measure, though context matters—73-75% of cotton's water footprint comes from rainfall, not irrigation.
items.example: Hemp requires about 50% less water than conventional cotton. Australian cotton is relatively efficient, producing more fibre per megalitre than most countries. Polyester's low water use must be weighed against its petroleum source and non-biodegradability.

subtopic.name: Sustainability in Fibre Production
subtopic.what: This subtopic examines the environmental impacts of different fibres, including water footprint, carbon emissions, microplastic pollution, and biodegradability. You will also learn about the mulesing controversy, textile waste, and circular economy approaches.
subtopic.why: Every fibre has environmental impacts. Understanding these helps you make informed consumer choices, evaluate sustainability claims, and recognise the complex trade-offs involved in textile production.

items.title: I can explain why wool has a relatively high carbon footprint
items.what: Wool has a carbon footprint of 19-25 kg CO₂e per kg of fibre. About 50% comes from sheep producing methane through digestion—approximately 30 litres of methane per sheep per day. This is higher than cotton (5.34 kg CO₂e/kg) or polyester (5.5-9.5 kg CO₂e/kg).
items.why: Understanding the sources of emissions helps evaluate the full environmental impact of natural fibres and recognise that natural does not automatically mean lower carbon.
items.example: Sheep belching accounts for half of wool's carbon footprint. Recycled polyester produces 79% lower emissions than virgin polyester. When comparing fibres, you must consider the complete lifecycle including production, use, and disposal.

items.title: I can describe the microplastics problem from synthetic textiles and identify solutions
items.what: Synthetic textiles contribute 35% of ocean microplastics. Each wash releases 640,000-1,500,000 microfibres that pass through filters and water treatment into waterways. Solutions include Guppyfriend washing bags, Cora Balls, less frequent washing, cooler wash cycles, and choosing natural fibres.
items.why: Microplastics are one of the most significant environmental issues facing the textile industry, affecting marine life and entering the human food chain.
items.example: Acrylic releases approximately 730,000 microfibres per wash—5 times more than polyester-cotton blends. Microplastics have been found in drinking water, food, and human blood. Washing synthetic items less frequently and using cooler water reduces microfibre release.

items.title: I can compare the biodegradability of different fibres
items.what: Decomposition times vary enormously: linen takes 2 weeks to a few months, cotton 1 week to 5 months, hemp similar to linen, wool 1-5 years, lyocell about 55 days, nylon 30-40 years, polyester 20-200 years, and acrylic approximately 200 years.
items.why: End-of-life impacts matter because the fashion industry produces about 92 million tonnes of textile waste globally each year, much of it going to landfill.
items.example: A polyester garment discarded today could still exist in landfill when your great-great-grandchildren are born. Natural fibres like linen and cotton can fully decompose within months under the right conditions. Lyocell offers a middle ground with 55-day decomposition.

items.title: I can explain the mulesing controversy and describe alternatives
items.what: Mulesing is a surgical procedure removing skin around a Merino sheep's tail to prevent flystrike (blowfly infestation). While it protects sheep from often-fatal suffering, it causes pain and distress. About 70% of Australian Merinos are mulesed; 17% of wool is sold as non-mulesed.
items.why: The mulesing debate illustrates the complex trade-offs between animal welfare, sheep health, and economic considerations in fibre production.
items.example: Victoria requires mandatory pain relief during mulesing. The National Wool Declaration allows growers to declare mulesing status. Alternatives include breeding for plain-bodied sheep that don't require the procedure. Some international buyers now refuse mulesed wool.

items.title: I can describe circular economy approaches to textile sustainability
items.what: A circular economy keeps materials in use through design for longevity, design for recyclability (single fibres rather than blends), repair and reuse, resale and donation, and recycling. Currently, global textile-to-textile recycling achieves less than 1%.
items.why: The linear model of extract-make-use-dispose is unsustainable. Understanding circular approaches helps identify more sustainable production and consumption patterns.
items.example: Australians discard approximately 23 kg of textiles per person per year to landfill—the 2nd highest per capita globally. Blended fabrics (like cotton-polyester) are very difficult to recycle. Certifications like Better Cotton Initiative, GOTS, and Responsible Wool Standard promote sustainable practices.

items.title: I can identify actions consumers can take to make more sustainable textile choices
items.what: Sustainable consumer actions include: buying less but choosing quality, preferring natural fibres that biodegrade, avoiding difficult-to-recycle blends, looking for certifications (GOTS, BCI, RWS), caring for clothes properly, washing synthetics carefully, donating or reselling, and supporting circular fashion brands.
items.why: Individual choices aggregate to significant impact. Understanding options empowers informed decision-making about textile purchases and care.
items.example: The average garment is worn only 7-10 times before being discarded. Washing synthetic items less frequently and in cooler water reduces microplastic release. 100% cotton is easier to recycle than a 60/40 cotton-polyester blend. Proper care extends garment life significantly.
